elements.content: Using different structural isomers (2,5-; 2,4-; 2;6-; 3,4-; 3,5-) of pyridinedicarboxylic acid, nine calcium-based coordination networks were synthesized under hydro-/solvothermal conditions and/or were produced via solvent recrystallization of previously synthesized compounds. The coordination networks reported were characterized using single crystal X-ray diffraction and thermal methods. They show diverse structural topologies, depending on the ligand geometry and coordinated solvent molecules, with inorganic connectivity motifs ranging from isolated octahedra to infinite chains, layer and a three-dimensional dense framework. The as-synthesized and desolvated networks further show structural transformation to hydrated phases through dissolution/reformation pathways. The process is likely driven by the high hydration energy of the calcium metal center.

The coordination networks reported were characterized using single crystal X-ray diffraction and thermal methods. elements.content: Nine calcium based coordination networks were synthesized using different structural isomers of pyridinedicarboxylate linker under hydro-/solvothermal conditions and/or solvent driven transformation. The variation of ligand geometry and the nature of coordinating solvents lead to the formation of networks of different topologies and thermal behaviors. The as-synthesized or desolvated networks undergo transformation exposed to water to form their corresponding hydrated phases.

The as-synthesized or desolvated networks undergo transformation exposed to water to form their corresponding hydrated phases.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination networks (CNs), formed by infinite arrays of metal centers connected by multifunctional organic linkers, are of current interest because of their potential applications in gas-storage, separation, catalysis, and sensing. Research had been recently centered on attempts to rationally design functional compounds with specific structures, by using a wide range of metal centers and organic linkers. Recognizable secondary-building units (SBUs) form between first row transition metals and polytypic carboxylate ligands. The presence of these SBUs raises hopes of the assembly of MOFs by design. Another group of functional hybrid materials, CNs formed from s-block metals, contains members that are lightweight (Li, Be, Mg), nontoxic, and readily available in nature, offering advantages in fields ranging from gas-adsorption to biomedical applications. Because of the predominantly nondirectional ionic metal–ligand interactions, SBUs are not as easily recognized in CNs formed from the s-block, and structural topology is governed by ligand geometries and functionalities. Thus, systematic studies of ligand geometry, as the important determinant of network architecture, are necessary for developing successful strategies for producing novel functional s-block CNs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination networks (CNs), formed by infinite arrays of metal centers connected by multifunctional organic linkers, are of current interest because of their potential applications in gas-storage, separation, catalysis, and sensing. Research had been recently centered on attempts to rationally design functional compounds with specific structures, by using a wide range of metal centers and organic linkers. Recognizable secondary-building units (SBUs) form between first row transition metals and polytypic carboxylate ligands. The presence of these SBUs raises hopes of the assembly of MOFs by design. Another group of functional hybrid materials, CNs formed from s-block metals, contains members that are lightweight (Li, Be, Mg), nontoxic, and readily available in nature, offering advantages in fields ranging from gas-adsorption to biomedical applications. Because of the predominantly nondirectional ionic metal-ligand interactions, SBUs are not as easily recognized in CNs formed from the s-block, and structural topology is governed by ligand geometries and functionalities. Thus, systematic studies of ligand geometry, as the important determinant of network architecture, are necessary for developing successful strategies for producing novel functional s-block CNs.

elements.content: In this work, a range of structural isomers of pyridinedicarboxylate (PDC) have been used to investigate the effect of bifunctional polydentate ligand architecture on the structure and stability of calcium-based CNs (Figure ). The role of calcium in natural CO2 separation and storage suggests research directed toward synthesis of calcium-based porous networks may also be fruitful. Various isomers of PDC were used previously to synthesize a series of lanthanides, first row transition, and s-block metals, where diverse coordination abilities were observed. PDC provides variable bridging and chelating coordination modes, due to the presence of both nitrogen- and oxygen-based functional groups alongside a rigid aromatic backbone. What is more, PDC forms six different structural isomers, where mutual orientation between functional groups varies between isomers, thereby facilitating studies of the relationships between ligand geometries and resultant CNs’ structural topologies using a relatively simple system.

elements.content: Apart from metal centers and organic linkers, external parameters such as temperature and synthesis solvents can also influence the topologies and properties of the materials produced. Solvent often influences the coordination behavior of the metal centers, which determine the connectivity and dimensionality of the network. The extent of deprotonation of organic carboxylate linkers that largely decides its coordination mode can be controlled by adjusting the basicity of the solvent medium. Along with the influence of synthesis solvent on network topology, several examples of postsynthesis solvent-induced structural transformation are reported in the literature. The desolvation–resolvation behavior is accompanied by changes in metal coordination geometry or network topology.

elements.content: Here we report nine calcium-based CNs, eight of which formed from different structural isomers of PDC-based linkers, and by varying the nature of the solvent used in hydro-/solvothermal syntheses methods. One of the networks was obtained by recrystallization of anhydrous solvothermally synthesized CN in the solvent containing water.
elements.clean_text: Here we report nine calcium-based CNs, eight of which formed from different structural isomers of PDC-based linkers, and by varying the nature of the solvent used in hydro-/solvothermal syntheses methods. One of the networks was obtained by recrystallization of anhydrous solvothermally synthesized CN in the solvent containing water.

elements.content: Eight coordination networks were synthesized under solvothermal conditions using Teflon lined 23-mL Parr stainless steel autoclaves. Starting materials include calcium nitrate tetrahydrate (Ca(NO3)2·4H2O, Acros-Organics, 99+% purity), normally anhydrous calcium chloride (CaCl2, Acros-Organics, 96% purity), 2,5- (Sigma-Aldrich 98% purity), 2,4- (Sigma-Aldrich 98% purity), 2,6- (Acros-Organics 99% purity), 3,4- (Acros-Organics 99% purity), 3,5- (Acros-Organics 98% purity) pyridinedicarboxylic acid (C7H6NO4), N,N-dimethylformamide (C3H7NO, DMF, Sigma-Aldrich 99% purity,) and ethanol (Fisher-Scientific, 95% purity). These reactants were used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Eight coordination networks were synthesized under solvothermal conditions using Teflon lined 23-mL Parr stainless steel autoclaves. Starting materials include calcium nitrate tetrahydrate (Ca(NO3)2⋅4H2O, Acros-Organics, 99+% purity), normally anhydrous calcium chloride (CaCl2, Acros-Organics, 96% purity), 2,5- (Sigma-Aldrich 98% purity), 2,4- (Sigma-Aldrich 98% purity), 2,6- (Acros-Organics 99% purity), 3,4- (Acros-Organics 99% purity), 3,5- (Acros-Organics 98% purity) pyridinedicarboxylic acid (C7H6NO4), N,N-dimethylformamide (C3H7NO, DMF, Sigma-Aldrich 99% purity,) and ethanol (Fisher-Scientific, 95% purity). These reactants were used without further purification.

elements.content: A typical synthesis involves 1 mmol of 2,5-PDC (0.167 g) and 1 mmol of Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (0.236 g) dissolved in a DMF/EtOH mixture (5.48 g/1.15 g) [molar ratio 1:1:75:25]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 180 °C. The product was obtained as needle-shaped crystals and washed with ethanol (yield 72%; 0.161 g).

elements.content: Compound 9 was made in impure form using 1 mmol of 3,5-PDC (0.167 g) and 1 mmol of CaCl2 (0.111 g) dissolved in DMF/H2O solution (3,65 g/1.9 g) [molar ratio: 1:1:50:50]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 100 °C. The product was obtained as a mixture of block-shaped crystals and unidentified powder. The single-crystal data were collected from crystals of this batch. Attempts to directly synthesize 9 as a pure compound from solvothermal routes were not successful. For example, using a variety of synthesis solvents, namely, DMF/water, pure water, water/ethanol, pure ethanol, in combination with different synthesis temperatures of 22, 60, 100, and 180 °C, and with or without NH4F mineralizer, failed to yield compound 9. However, pure compound 9 was obtained from compound 8 through solvent-driven structural transformation, which is discussed in detail below.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Ca(3,5-PDC)(H2O)2] n , 9 

Compound 9 was made in impure form using 1 mmol of 3,5-PDC (0.167 g) and 1 mmol of CaCl2 (0.111 g) dissolved in DMF/H2O solution (3,65 g/1.9 g) [molar ratio: 1:1:50:50]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 100 °C. The product was obtained as a mixture of block-shaped crystals and unidentified powder. The single-crystal data were collected from crystals of this batch. Attempts to directly synthesize 9 as a pure compound from solvothermal routes were not successful. For example, using a variety of synthesis solvents, namely, DMF/water, pure water, water/ethanol, pure ethanol, in combination with different synthesis temperatures of 22, 60, 100, and 180 °C, and with or without NH4F mineralizer, failed to yield compound 9. However, pure compound 9 was obtained from compound 8 through solvent-driven structural transformation, which is discussed in detail below.

elements.content: Suitable crystals of each compound were selected from the bulk residue of filtration and were then mounted on glass fibers using epoxy. Reflections for compounds 1 and 3–9 were collected using a four-circle kappa Oxford Gemini diffractometer equipped with an Atlas detector (λ = 0.71073 Å) with 1° ω-scans at room temperature (298 K). The raw intensity data were collected, integrated, and corrected for absorption effects using CrysAlis PRO software. Reflections for compound 2 were collected using a Bruker four circle P4-single crystal diffractometer equipped with a SMART 1K CCD detector at room temperature (298 K) using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with φ and ω scans. The raw intensity data were collected and integrated with software packages SMART and SAINT followed by empirical absorption corrections using SADABS. The crystal structures of 1–9 were solved using direct methods (SHELXS). Calcium and oxygen atoms were located first followed by determination of other atom positions (C, N) from Fourier difference maps. Most of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically (). Hydrogen atoms were added to the structure model using geometrical constraints. A summary of some important crystallographic details can be found in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Suitable crystals of each compound were selected from the bulk residue of filtration and were then mounted on glass fibers using epoxy. Reflections for compounds 1 and 3-9 were collected using a four-circle kappa Oxford Gemini diffractometer equipped with an Atlas detector (λ = 0.71073 Å) with 1° ω-scans at room temperature (298 K). The raw intensity data were collected, integrated, and corrected for absorption effects using CrysAlis PRO software. Reflections for compound 2 were collected using a Bruker four circle P4-single crystal diffractometer equipped with a SMART 1K CCD detector at room temperature (298 K) using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with φ and ω scans. The raw intensity data were collected and integrated with software packages SMART and SAINT followed by empirical absorption corrections using SADABS. The crystal structures of 1-9 were solved using direct methods (SHELXS). Calcium and oxygen atoms were located first followed by determination of other atom positions (C, N) from Fourier difference maps. Most of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically (). Hydrogen atoms were added to the structure model using geometrical constraints. A summary of some important crystallographic details can be found in Table .

Bulk sample identification and determination of phase purity were done using powder X-ray diffraction. The data were collected using a Rigaku Ultima-IV diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation within a range of 5° ≤ 2Θ ≤ 40° (scanning rate: 1°/min). The powder patterns so collected were consistent with the powder patterns simulated based on the single crystal data ().

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data for compounds 1–9 were collected using a TGA Q500 instrument. The samples were heated from room temperature to 750 °C under a N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min ().
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data for compounds 1-9 were collected using a TGA Q500 instrument. The samples were heated from room temperature to 750 °C under a N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min ().

elements.content: Approximately 0.05 g of each compound was placed in glass vial with 10 mL of solvents: H2O, EtOH, MeOH, for solubility studies. Solvents were refreshed every day for 7 days, or until total dissolution. In the transformation study approximately 0.05 g of desolvated compounds 1–5 and 8 was placed in 10 mL of solvents: H2O, EtOH, MeOH, and DMF for 2 days without decanting. The samples were recovered by solvent evaporation.
elements.clean_text:
Solubility and Solvent-Driven Transformation

Approximately 0.05 g of each compound was placed in glass vial with 10 mL of solvents: H2O, EtOH, MeOH, for solubility studies. Solvents were refreshed every day for 7 days, or until total dissolution. In the transformation study approximately 0.05 g of desolvated compounds 1-5 and 8 was placed in 10 mL of solvents: H2O, EtOH, MeOH, and DMF for 2 days without decanting. The samples were recovered by solvent evaporation.

elements.content: Calcium can adopt different coordination numbers with oxygen and/or nitrogen. In compounds 1–9 Ca ions are present in combinations of 6-, 7-, or 8- coordinated environments () with the functional groups of PDC or solvent molecules. The average metal–oxygen bond is 2.40 (±0.09) Å, with the range of distances from 2.263(2) Å to 2.692(1) Å (). The metal–oxygen bond length increases with calcium coordination number from 6 to 8, with an average of 2.32 (±0.04) Å for 6-coordinated, 2.40 (±0.04) Å for 7-coordinated and 2.46 (±0.08) Å for 8-coordinated environment. Pyridyl nitrogen atoms display two different coordination behaviors  chelating Ca together with one or two carboxylate oxygen atoms from the same linker (1–6), or bridging (8–9) different metal centers. The average Ca–N bond length is 2.56 (±0.04) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description

Calcium can adopt different coordination numbers with oxygen and/or nitrogen. In compounds 1-9 Ca ions are present in combinations of 6-, 7-, or 8- coordinated environments () with the functional groups of PDC or solvent molecules. The average metal-oxygen bond is 2.40 (±0.09) Å, with the range of distances from 2.263(2) Å to 2.692(1) Å (). The metal-oxygen bond length increases with calcium coordination number from 6 to 8, with an average of 2.32 (±0.04) Å for 6-coordinated, 2.40 (±0.04) Å for 7-coordinated and 2.46 (±0.08) Å for 8-coordinated environment. Pyridyl nitrogen atoms display two different coordination behaviors  chelating Ca together with one or two carboxylate oxygen atoms from the same linker (1-6), or bridging (8-9) different metal centers. The average Ca-N bond length is 2.56 (±0.04) Å.

elements.content: The structural motifs found in compounds 1–9 are illustrated in Figure . The Ca2+ metal centers are bridged by carboxylate groups and/or pyridyl nitrogen atoms, forming different cationic building blocks ranging from monomers (8, 9), dimers (8), tetramers (1), chains (2–5), layer (7) and a 3-D network (6). The organic linkers show variable coordination, involving either chelating or bridging mode, or a combination of both (Figure ).

The organic linkers show variable coordination, involving either chelating or bridging mode, or a combination of both (Figure ).

elements.content: The geometry of the PDC linker dictate the topology of the Ca-PDC networks formed. Organic linkers 2,5- and 2,4-PDC display very similar connectivity to metal centers, where pyridyl nitrogen and one carboxylate oxygen atom are present in chelating positions with calcium. Such connectivity leads to the formation of four networks with similar structural topologies. Except 1, compounds based on 2,4- and 2,5-PDC (2–5) are constructed of infinite chains of corner (2) or edge (3–5) connected Ca polyhedra, parallel to one of the unit cell axes (b for 2 and 4, a for 3 and 5). The chains are further linked together by organic ligands, which results in formation of three-dimensional (3-D) structures (Figure ). The asymmetric units of the resultant structures comprise one unique metal center and one complete organic ligand plus one solvent molecule. In each material the PDC linker connects to five calcium metal centers (Figure ). The metal coordination sphere is quite similar in compounds 3–5, where calcium is coordinating to five organic linkers and one solvent molecule, with a coordination number of 7 (2) or 8 (3–5). The PDC carboxylate groups do not chelate to the Ca center in compound 2, but rather bridge the adjacent metals, which results in a lower coordination number. The calculated theoretical porosity is 4%, 42%, 0%, and 35% for 2–5, respectively, showing that networks incorporating DMF molecules are much more open and potentially porous than ones containing water.

Such connectivity leads to the formation of four networks with similar structural topologies. Except 1, compounds based on 2,4- and 2,5-PDC (2-5) are constructed of infinite chains of corner (2) or edge (3-5) connected Ca polyhedra, parallel to one of the unit cell axes (b for 2 and 4, a for 3 and 5). The chains are further linked together by organic ligands, which results in formation of three-dimensional (3-D) structures (Figure ). The asymmetric units of the resultant structures comprise one unique metal center and one complete organic ligand plus one solvent molecule. The metal coordination sphere is quite similar in compounds 3-5, where calcium is coordinating to five organic linkers and one solvent molecule, with a coordination number of 7 (2) or 8 (3-5). The PDC carboxylate groups do not chelate to the Ca center in compound 2, but rather bridge the adjacent metals, which results in a lower coordination number. The calculated theoretical porosity is 4%, 42%, 0%, and 35% for 2-5, respectively, showing that networks incorporating DMF molecules are much more open and potentially porous than ones containing water.

elements.content: Compound 1 shows different inorganic connectivity compared to other networks of the same metal-linker system (2, 3). It is composed of edge sharing tetrameric calcium polyhedra, connected by organic linkers, which results in a 3-D network. The asymmetric unit of 1 comprises four crystallographically different calcium atoms, four organic ligands, and one DMF molecule coordinated to Ca3. In this compound, calcium is either 7- (Ca1, Ca2, Ca3) or 6- (Ca4) coordinated, and PDC is connecting to five or six different metal centers (Figure ).

It is composed of edge sharing tetrameric calcium polyhedra, connected by organic linkers, which results in a 3-D network. The asymmetric unit of 1 comprises four crystallographically different calcium atoms, four organic ligands, and one DMF molecule coordinated to Ca3. In this compound, calcium is either 7- (Ca1, Ca2, Ca3) or 6- (Ca4) coordinated, and PDC is connecting to five or six different metal centers (Figure ).

elements.content: In 6 there is only one unique 7-coordinated metal center with distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, one unique 2,6-PDC ligand, and no solvent molecules. The specific geometry of 2,6-PDC allows tridentate chelating mode, where the metal is surrounded by nitrogen and two oxygen atoms. The carboxylate groups are further turned from aromatic plane by 31.19° and 18.49° bridging to next metal center, which leads to the formation of a hexagonal dense framework of inorganic connectivity. Each Ca polyhedron is connected to three others, sharing one edge and two corners. The PDC carboxylate groups are coordinated in a monodentate or monodentate bridging fashion, and every organic linker is connected to five calcium ions. The extended structure of compound 6 shows empty hexagonal tunnels parallel to the c axis (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: In 6 there is only one unique 7-coordinated metal center with distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, one unique 2,6-PDC ligand, and no solvent molecules. The specific geometry of 2,6-PDC allows tridentate chelating mode, where the metal is surrounded by nitrogen and two oxygen atoms. The carboxylate groups are further turned from aromatic plane by 31.19° and 18.49° bridging to next metal center, which leads to the formation of a hexagonal dense framework of inorganic connectivity. Each Ca polyhedron is connected to three others, sharing one edge and two corners. The PDC carboxylate groups are coordinated in a monodentate or monodentate bridging fashion, and every organic linker is connected to five calcium ions. The extended structure of compound 6 shows empty hexagonal tunnels parallel to the c axis (Figure ).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of compound 7 consists of one crystallographically unique calcium metal center, one linker, and a coordinated water molecule. The calcium polyhedra are joined in edge or corner sharing fashion, forming a layered M-O-M connectivity. The inorganic layer is stacked between organic layers, formed by the linkers. The geometry of the 3,4-PDC governs the topology of compound 7 as seen in other compounds. The distance between the pyridyl nitrogen and carboxylate groups is crucial, as in compound 7 only carboxylate oxygen atoms coordinate with the metal centers, forming a layered network. The linker shows diverse coordination modes, ranging from monodentate, monodentate bridging and bidendate chelating (Figure ). In the crystal structure, extensive O–H···N hydrogen-bonding interaction between hydrogen from water and pyridyl nitrogen leads to the formation of a 3-D supramolecular network (Figure ).

elements.content: Both compounds 8 and 9 are formed by a combination of calcium metal centers, connected by the 3,5-PDC linker, though the structural topologies are quite different. The coplanar arrangement of carboxylate groups with the pyridine ring facilitates the formation of planar metal–ligand connectivity, as previously reported in the case of Mg-3,5-PDC (Figure ). The asymmetric unit of compound 8 consists of four unique calcium metal centers, three organic linkers, and four coordinated DMF molecules. One of the PDC linkers connects planes together to form the 3-D network. Three of the unique calcium metal centers (Ca1, Ca3, Ca4) are present in distorted octahedral coordination, with DMF molecules either at the vertexes of the octahedra (Ca1, Ca3) or occupying one of the coordination sites (Ca4). The fourth calcium center (Ca2) is present in seven-coordinated environment, with six carboxylate oxygen atoms and one DMF molecule. One of the carboxylate groups is present in chelating mode, while others are bridging the adjacent Ca atoms. The asymmetric unit of compound 9 is composed of one unique calcium center, an organic linker, and two solvent water molecules. The calcium metal center is present in pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, where the apexes are occupied by water molecules and four planar corners belong to two chelating carboxylate groups. The fifth planar coordination sites are occupied by pyridyl nitrogen. Each organic linker is connected with three calcium centers to form the layered network; terminal water molecules occupy calcium coordination sites, which might otherwise lead to connectivity in the third dimension.

elements.content: Attempts to obtain novel multidimensional CNs require optimization of a number of parameters in the synthesis, including the nature of the metal salt, solvent type, and temperature. Both solvothermal and hydrothermal reaction conditions were employed in the present case, to study the formation of Ca-PDC networks. A preliminary study was performed on the Ca-2,5-PDC system, in order to rationalize the choice of a limited subset of solvents (Table ). As a result it was found that water, when used in combination with other solvents (DMF, methanol, and ethanol), always favors the formation of hydrated compound 2. Similar results were previously observed in the Mg-3,5-PDC system, showing overwhelming preference to form hydrated phases. On the basis of these preliminary results, DMF, water, ethanol, and their 1:1 molar combinations were chosen as the preferred synthesis solvents. In retrospect the choice is intuitive, as polar synthesis solvents are expected to favor the formation of ionic calcium coordination networks. Following the preliminary study to narrow the choice of solvents (Table ), in total nine CNs were synthesized based on five structural isomers of the PDC linker. However, after repeated synthetic attempts using (a) higher solvent ratios and (b) addition of mineralizer NH4F, we were unable to synthesize any Ca-2,3-PDC networks. Instead, phase pure α-calcium formate is formed, when DMF is used in pure or mixture forms, as a result of thermal decomposition of DMF molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Variation of Synthetic Parameters

Attempts to obtain novel multidimensional CNs require optimization of a number of parameters in the synthesis, including the nature of the metal salt, solvent type, and temperature. Both solvothermal and hydrothermal reaction conditions were employed in the present case, to study the formation of Ca-PDC networks. A preliminary study was performed on the Ca-2,5-PDC system, in order to rationalize the choice of a limited subset of solvents (Table ). As a result it was found that water, when used in combination with other solvents (DMF, methanol, and ethanol), always favors the formation of hydrated compound 2. Similar results were previously observed in the Mg-3,5-PDC system, showing overwhelming preference to form hydrated phases. On the basis of these preliminary results, DMF, water, ethanol, and their 1:1 molar combinations were chosen as the preferred synthesis solvents. In retrospect the choice is intuitive, as polar synthesis solvents are expected to favor the formation of ionic calcium coordination networks. Following the preliminary study to narrow the choice of solvents (Table ), in total nine CNs were synthesized based on five structural isomers of the PDC linker. However, after repeated synthetic attempts using (a) higher solvent ratios and (b) addition of mineralizer NH4F, we were unable to synthesize any Ca-2,3-PDC networks. Instead, phase pure α-calcium formate is formed, when DMF is used in pure or mixture forms, as a result of thermal decomposition of DMF molecules.

The thermal stability of the compounds 1–9 under N2 atmosphere depends on their structural topologies and the nature of the coordinated solvents. Compound 6 exhibits the highest stability up to 580 °C due to the absence of any coordinated or free solvent molecules. Compound 1 shows a similar one-step decomposition pathway and is stable up to 480 °C. The presence of coordinated DMF within the void rather than in a channel might be the reason for higher thermal stability of compound 1, with respect to other networks possessing coordinated solvents. All other compounds show the expected two-step decomposition pathways of solvent removal, followed by decomposition. Compounds with coordinated water molecules show higher thermal stability over the ones with coordinated DMF molecules, and this is attributed to stronger Ca–water bonding.
elements.clean_text:
Activation and Solvent Dependent Structural Transformations

The thermal stability of the compounds 1-9 under N2 atmosphere depends on their structural topologies and the nature of the coordinated solvents. Compound 6 exhibits the highest stability up to 580 °C due to the absence of any coordinated or free solvent molecules. Compound 1 shows a similar one-step decomposition pathway and is stable up to 480 °C. The presence of coordinated DMF within the void rather than in a channel might be the reason for higher thermal stability of compound 1, with respect to other networks possessing coordinated solvents. All other compounds show the expected two-step decomposition pathways of solvent removal, followed by decomposition. Compounds with coordinated water molecules show higher thermal stability over the ones with coordinated DMF molecules, and this is attributed to stronger Ca-water bonding.

elements.content: The networks with theoretical porosity in their desolvated form were tested for gas-adsorption properties after activation. They were all found nonporous based on N2 adsorption experiments and poorly crystalline, based on the lack of sharp Bragg peaks in their powder XRD patterns. Further, the solubility of as-synthesized and activated networks 1–8 was tested using water and common alcohols, for example, ethanol and methanol. All the as-synthesized compounds were found to be soluble in water except for 3 and 4.
elements.clean_text: The networks with theoretical porosity in their desolvated form were tested for gas-adsorption properties after activation. They were all found nonporous based on N2 adsorption experiments and poorly crystalline, based on the lack of sharp Bragg peaks in their  powder XRD patterns. Further, the solubility of as-synthesized and activated networks 1-8 was tested using water and common alcohols, for example, ethanol and methanol. All the as-synthesized compounds were found to be soluble in water except for 3 and 4.

elements.content: Freshly made and activated samples of compounds 1, 2, and 3 (Ca-2,5-PDC) were immersed in water, methanol, and ethanol to study the solvent driver transformation (Figure ). With the exception of compound 1 immersed in ethanol, where the powder XRD of the recovered material shows that it transformed to unknown microcrystalline material, sample 2 resulted after evaporation of solvent. On the other hand, exposing activated samples 2 and 3 to DMF leads to formation of compound 3. The activated compound 1 reverts to its original crystalline form upon exposure to solvent DMF. Compounds 5 and 8 transform to hydrated phases 4 and 9, respectively, after immersing both the activated and freshly made samples in water, ethanol, and methanol (Figure ). The exposure of 4, 5, and 8 to DMF did not lead to formation or recovering of crystallinity of DMF-containing phases. Transformation to hydrated phases was previously reported by Liang et al. in other calcium-based CNs. The formation of the hydrated phases from either as-synthesized or activated compounds might follow a dissolution–reformation pathway, which is driven by the high hydration energy of the calcium metal center (H hyd = −1577 kJ/mol).

With the exception of compound 1 immersed in ethanol, where the powder XRD of the recovered material shows that it transformed to unknown microcrystalline material, sample 2 resulted after evaporation of solvent. On the other hand, exposing activated samples 2 and 3 to DMF leads to formation of compound 3. The activated compound 1 reverts to its original crystalline form upon exposure to solvent DMF. Compounds 5 and 8 transform to hydrated phases 4 and 9, respectively, after immersing both the activated and freshly made samples in water, ethanol, and methanol (Figure ). The exposure of 4, 5, and 8 to DMF did not lead to formation or recovering of crystallinity of DMF-containing phases. Transformation to hydrated phases was previously reported by Liang et al. in other calcium-based CNs. The formation of the hydrated phases from either as-synthesized or activated compounds might follow a dissolution-reformation pathway, which is driven by the high hydration energy of the calcium metal center (H hyd  = -1577 kJ/mol).

elements.content: The atomic arrangements in nine calcium-pyridinedicarboxylate based CNs, synthesized under solvothermal conditions or by solvent-driven transformation, are based on a variety of inorganic structural motifs, ranging from isolated polyhedra to infinite chains, layer or a 3-D connectivity, depending on the linker geometry and synthetic conditions. The motif formed depends on orientation of the carboxylates with respect to the pyridyl nitrogen group and the nature of coordinated solvent. For example, Ca-3,5-PDC (8–9) networks consist of monomers and dimers of calcium polyhedra, while Ca-2,6-PDC (6) has a 3-D inorganic connectivity. In both cases, the mutual angles between the carboxylate groups are the same (120°), though the close proximity of pyridyl nitrogen atom to the carboxylate groups in 2,6-PDC favors the 3-D connectivity. The as-synthesized and desolvated networks show structural transformation to hydrated phases in the presence of water through dissolution/reformation pathways involving calcium coordination spheres.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The atomic arrangements in nine calcium-pyridinedicarboxylate based CNs, synthesized under solvothermal conditions or by solvent-driven transformation, are based on a variety of inorganic structural motifs, ranging from isolated polyhedra to infinite chains, layer or a 3-D connectivity, depending on the linker geometry and synthetic conditions. The motif formed depends on orientation of the carboxylates with respect to the pyridyl nitrogen group and the nature of coordinated solvent. For example, Ca-3,5-PDC (8-9) networks consist of monomers and dimers of calcium polyhedra, while Ca-2,6-PDC (6) has a 3-D inorganic connectivity. In both cases, the mutual angles between the carboxylate groups are the same (120°), though the close proximity of pyridyl nitrogen atom to the carboxylate groups in 2,6-PDC favors the 3-D connectivity. The as-synthesized and desolvated networks show structural transformation to hydrated phases in the presence of water through dissolution/reformation pathways involving calcium coordination spheres.

A typical synthesis involves 1 mmol of 2,5-PDC (0.167 g) and 1 mmol of Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (0.236 g) dissolved in a DMF/EtOH mixture (5.48 g/1.15 g) [molar ratio 1:1:75:25]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 180 °C. The product was obtained as needle-shaped crystals and washed with ethanol (yield 72%; 0.161 g).

Synthesis of [Ca(2,5-PDC)(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>, <bold>2</bold>

A typical synthesis involves 1 mmol of 2,5-PDC (0.167 g) and 1 mmol of CaCl2 (0.111 g) dissolved in DMF/H2O solution (3.65 g/1.9 g) [molar ratio 1:1:50:50]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 180 °C. The product was obtained as needle-shaped crystals and washed with ethanol (yield 68%; 0.152 g).

Synthesis of [Ca(2,5-PDC)(DMF)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>, <bold>3</bold>

A typical synthesis involves 1 mmol of 2,5-PDC (0.167 g) and 1 mmol of CaCl2 (0.111 g) dissolved in 7.3 g of DMF [molar ratio 1:1:100]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 180 °C. The product was obtained as block-shaped crystals and washed with ethanol (yield 64%; 0.178 g).

Synthesis of [Ca(2,4-PDC)(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>, <bold>4</bold>

A typical synthesis involves 1 mmol of 2,4-PDC·H2O (0.185 g) and 1 mmol of CaCl2 (0.111 g) dissolved in DMF/H2O solution (3.65 g/1.9 g), [molar ratio 1:1:50:50]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 180 °C. The product was obtained as needle-shaped crystals and washed with ethanol (yield 73%; 0.163 g).

Synthesis of [Ca(2,4-PDC)(DMF)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>, <bold>5</bold>

A typical synthesis involves 1 mmol of 2,4-PDC·H2O (0.185 g) and 1 mmol of CaCl2 (0.111 g) dissolved in 7.3 g of DMF [molar ratio 1:1:100]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 180 °C. The product was obtained as block-shaped crystals and washed with ethanol (yield 69%; 0.192 g).

Synthesis of [Ca (2,6-PDC)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>, <bold>6</bold>

A typical synthesis involves 1 mmol of 2,6-PDC (0.167 g) and 1 mmol of CaCl2 (0.111 g) dissolved in DMF/H2O solution (3.65 g/1.9 g) [molar ratio 1:1:50:50]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 180 °C. The product was obtained as block-shaped crystals and washed with ethanol (yield 84%; 0.172 g).

Synthesis of [Ca<sub>4</sub>(3,4-PDC)<sub>4</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>, <bold>7</bold>

A typical synthesis involves 1 mmol of 3,4-PDC (0.167 g) and 1 mmol of CaCl2 (0.111 g) dissolved in a DMF/H2O solution (3,65 g/1.9 g) [molar ratio 1:1:50:50]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 180 °C. The product was obtained as plate-shaped crystals and washed with ethanol (yield 58%; 0.129 g).

Synthesis of [Ca(3,5-PDC)(DMF)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>, <bold>8</bold>

A typical synthesis involves 1 mmol of 3,5-PDC (0.167 g) and 1 mmol of CaCl2 (0.111 g) dissolved in 7.3 g of DMF [molar ratio 1:1:100]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 100 °C. The product was obtained as block-shaped crystal and washed with ethanol (yield 76%; 0.231 g).

Synthesis of [Ca(3,5-PDC)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>, <bold>9</bold>

Compound 9 was made in impure form using 1 mmol of 3,5-PDC (0.167 g) and 1 mmol of CaCl2 (0.111 g) dissolved in DMF/H2O solution (3,65 g/1.9 g) [molar ratio: 1:1:50:50]. The resultant mixture was stirred for 2 h to achieve homogeneity and heated for 5 days at 100 °C. The product was obtained as a mixture of block-shaped crystals and unidentified powder. The single-crystal data were collected from crystals of this batch. Attempts to directly synthesize 9 as a pure compound from solvothermal routes were not successful. For example, using a variety of synthesis solvents, namely, DMF/water, pure water, water/ethanol, pure ethanol, in combination with different synthesis temperatures of 22, 60, 100, and 180 °C, and with or without NH4F mineralizer, failed to yield compound 9. However, pure compound 9 was obtained from compound 8 through solvent-driven structural transformation, which is discussed in detail below.

Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity.
